Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Story: The phone buzzed in my pocket as I scanned the radar, my headset crackling with pilots’ anxious voices. “Tower, holding at waypoint, fuel’s getting low.” My eyes darted between blips, calculating altitudes, spacing, and the safest sequence. The holiday was in full swing at home—my mother’s voice on the voicemail, gentle but insistent: “We’re waiting for you to start the family blessing. It’s tradition, you know.” I could almost smell the incense, hear my father’s laughter, the clatter of dishes. But here, in the dim glow of the control room, I was the only one on shift with enough experience to untangle this mess. The expectation to keep everyone safe pressed on me as heavily as the hope in my mother’s words. I felt split in two—one part longing to be the dutiful son, the other tethered to the radar, responsible for hundreds of lives. The clock ticked, the voices in my ear grew more urgent, and my family’s call echoed in my mind. I stared at the screen, heart pounding, torn between the sky and home.
